questions.text: A young man who collapsed at a concert was suspected to have bacterial meningitis. The other attendees of the concert were administered ciprofloxacin by the medical staff on duty. What is this kind of antimicrobial therapy called?
questions.solution:
The antimicrobial treatment initiated in a patient who is not yet infected is called prophylactic therapy. The goal is to prevent infection in some patients and to prevent dangerous manifestations of infections in other patients. 

Option A: Preemptive therapy is therapy in an asymptomatic individual with evidence of infection (high-risk).

Option C: Empirical therapy is broad-spectrum therapy in a patient with symptoms of infection but no microbiological confirmation of the causative agent. 

Option D: Suppressive therapy is given to patients when the infection is controlled but not completely eradicated by the initial round of antimicrobial treatment. This is usually indicated for immunosuppressed patients.

questions.text: The total microbial population was found to be susceptible to antimicrobials on testing but a subset of the same population was resistant which was undetected. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
Heteroresistance occurs when a subset of the total microbial population is resistant, despite the total microbial population being susceptible on testing. The resistant subpopulation is usually well below the assay-detection limits. 

Heteroresistant Staphylococci and M. tuberculosis have led to therapeutic failures and mortality. C. albicans and C. neoformans with heteroresistance to fluconazole have resulted in increased treatment failures.

Note: For viruses, the resistant viral species occurring due to the above phenomenon is termed as 'quasi-species'. Quasi-species resistant to antiretroviral agents have resulted in the failure of antiretroviral therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs shows concentration-dependent killing?
questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides exhibit concentration-dependent killing and are preferably dosed once daily for maximum effect.

Peak concentration above MIC (minimum inhibitory concentration) matters for certain classes of drugs for their antimicrobial action. It is referred to as concentration-dependent killing. The period during which the concentration remains above MIC is not relevant for such drugs. Aminoglycosides and quinolones have this property.

Time-dependent killing: The antimicrobial action is dependent on the period for which the concentration of drug remains above the MIC. Penicillins, 5-fluorocytosine and vancomycin have this property.

questions.text: A patient having pneumococcal pneumonia could not be treated using penicillin G as the microbe was found to be resistant to it. How is this resistance mainly acquired?
questions.solution: Transformation is the molecular basis of penicillin G resistance in pneumococci and meningococci.

questions.text: What is the extrachromosomal DNA present in bacteria that transmits drug resistance called?
questions.solution:
Drug resistance transmitting extrachromosomal DNA present in bacteria is a plasmid.

They are usually involved in the horizontal transfer of drug resistance gene in bacteria. Chromosomal DNA can also be involved in the transfer of resistance.

questions.text: How is multidrug resistance transferred among bacteria?
questions.solution:
Multidrug resistance is transferred through conjugation. 

Multiple genes, each encoding for resistance to a drug can be present in a single bacterial cell. Typically such genes are present on resistance (R) plasmids. The main mode of transfer of resistant gene-containing plasmids is through conjugation.

questions.text: An example of a bacteriostatic drug is ______
questions.solution:
Linezolid is an example of a bacteriostatic drug.

questions.text: You want to prescribe a bactericidal drug to a patient having an infection. Which of the following drugs will you not choose?
questions.solution:
Tigecycline is not a bactericidal drug. Tigecycline belongs to a new class of glycylcyclines which is a congener of teteracycline . It is a protein synthesis inhibitor and generally considered as a bacteriostatic.

Isoniazid, daptomycin and ciprofloxacin are all bactericidal agents.

questions.text: A patient developed a surgical site infection with Klebsiella, which is found to be sensitive to a cell wall synthesis inhibitor. Which of the following antibiotics is this likely to be?
questions.solution:
Cefepime is an antibiotic that acts by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

Cefepime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin. Cephalosporins act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

Aminoglycosides, doxycycline, and erythromycin are protein synthesis inhibitors. 

Related Pearl: Cell wall synthesis inhibitors (mnemonic "BBC Van")

BBC Van:

  • Beta lactams
  • Bacitracin
  • Cycloserine
  • Vancomycin
  • Fosfomycin

questions.text: A patient has presented to your OPD complaining of vomiting and rice water stools. You decide to treat him with a protein synthesis inhibitor. Which antibiotic do you choose?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline is a tetracycline that acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. It is the drug of choice for cholera.

Options A & D: Cefotetan and oxacillin are beta-lactam antibiotics that act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

Option C: Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone that acts by inhibiting DNA gyrase.

questions.text: Which of the following antibacterial agents does not act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis?
questions.solution:
Nitrofurantoin is an antibacterial drug that does not act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

The antibacterial activity of nitrofurantoin appears to correlate with the rapid intracellular conversion of nitrofurantoin to highly reactive intermediates by bacterial reductases. These intermediates react nonspecifically with many ribosomal proteins and disrupt the synthesis of proteins,Â RNA, DNA, and metabolic processes.

Carbapenems, monobactams, and cephalosporins are beta-lactam antibiotics that act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

questions.text: You are studying the susceptibility of Streptococci to bacitracin in the lab. What is the site of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Bacitracin acts on the cell wall by inhibiting the synthesis of the cell wall.

It interferes with the dephosphorylation of bactoprenol (lipid carrier) which carries peptidoglycan subunits outside the cell membrane to the growing cell wall. It can also alter the integrity of the cell membrane.

Bacitracin is mainly active against gram-positive cocci and bacilli.
